reviewQuestions_cap1.questionText: Which of the following does not contribute significantly to the operational value of a large cloud provider like AWS?

options.A: Multiregional presence
options.B: Highly experienced teams of security engineers
options.C: Deep experience in the retail sphere
options.D: Metered, pay-per-use pricing

reviewQuestions_cap1.explanation: Having globally distributed infrastructure and experienced security engineers makes a provider’s infrastructure more reliable. Metered pricing makes a wider range of workloads possible.

reviewQuestions_cap1.questionText: Which of the following are signs of a highly available application? (Choose two.)

options.A: A failure in one geographic region will trigger an automatic failover to resources in a different region.
options.B: Applications are protected behind multiple layers of security.
options.C: Virtualized hypervisor-driven systems are deployed as mandated by company policy.
options.D: Spikes in user demand are met through automatically increasing resources.

answer: A failure in one geographic region will trigger an automatic failover to resources in a different region.
Spikes in user demand are met through automatically increasing resources.
reviewQuestions_cap1.explanation: Security and virtualization are both important characteristics of successful cloud workloads, but neither will directly impact availability.

reviewQuestions_cap1.questionText: How does the metered payment model make many benefits of cloud computing possible? (Choose two.)

options.A: Greater application security is now possible.
options.B: Experiments with multiple configuration options are now cost-effective.
options.C: Applications are now highly scalable.
options.D: Full-stack applications are possible without the need to invest in capital expenses.

answer: Experiments with multiple configuration options are now cost-effective.
Full-stack applications are possible without the need to invest in capital expenses.
reviewQuestions_cap1.explanation: Security and scalability are important cloud elements but are not related to metered pricing.

reviewQuestions_cap1.questionText: Which of the following are direct benefits of server virtualization? (Choose two.)

options.A: Fast resource provisioning and launching
options.B: Efficient (high-density) use of resources
options.C: Greater application security
options.D: Elastic application designs

reviewQuestions_cap1.explanation: Security and elasticity are important but are not directly related to server virtualization.

options.A: Hardware device used to provide an interface between storage and compute modules
options.B: Hardware device used to provide an interface between networking and compute modules
options.C: Software used to log and monitor virtualized operations
options.D: Software used to administer virtualized resources run on physical infrastructure

reviewQuestions_cap1.answer: Software used to administer virtualized resources run on physical infrastructure
reviewQuestions_cap1.explanation: A hypervisor is software (not hardware) that administers virtualized operations.

reviewQuestions_cap1.questionText: Which of the following best describes server virtualization?

options.A: “Sharding” data from multiple sources into a single virtual data store
options.B: Logically partitioning physical compute and storage devices into multiple smaller virtual devices
options.C: Aggregating physical resources spread over multiple physical devices into a single virtual device
options.D: Abstracting the complexity of physical infrastructure behind a simple web interface

reviewQuestions_cap1.answer: Logically partitioning physical compute and storage devices into multiple smaller virtual devices
reviewQuestions_cap1.explanation: Sharding, aggregating remote resources, and abstracting complex infrastructure can all be accomplished using virtualization techniques, but they aren’t, of themselves, virtualization.

reviewQuestions_cap1.questionText: Which of the following best describes infrastructure-as-a-service products?

options.A: Services that hide infrastructure complexity behind a simple interface
options.B: Services that provide a service to end users through a public network
options.C: Services that give you direct control over underlying compute and storage resources
options.D: Platforms that allow developers to run their code over short periods on cloud servers

reviewQuestions_cap1.answer: Services that give you direct control over underlying compute and storage resources
reviewQuestions_cap1.explanation: PaaS products mask complexity, SaaS products provide end‐user services, and serverless architectures (like AWS Lambda) let developers run code on cloud servers.

reviewQuestions_cap1.questionText: Which of the following best describes platform-as-a-service products?

options.A: Services that hide infrastructure complexity behind a simple interface
options.B: Platforms that allow developers to run their code over short periods on cloud servers
options.C: Services that give you direct control over underlying compute and storage resources
options.D: Services that provide a service to end users through a public network

reviewQuestions_cap1.answer: Services that hide infrastructure complexity behind a simple interface
reviewQuestions_cap1.explanation: IaaS products provide full infrastructure access, SaaS products provide end‐user services, and serverless architectures (like AWS Lambda) let developers run code on cloud servers.

reviewQuestions_cap1.questionText: Which of the following best describes software-as-a-service products?

options.A: Services that give you direct control over underlying compute and storage resources
options.B: Services that provide a service to end users through a public network
options.C: Services that hide infrastructure complexity behind a simple interface
options.D: Platforms that allow developers to run their code over short periods on cloud servers

reviewQuestions_cap1.answer: Services that provide a service to end users through a public network
reviewQuestions_cap1.explanation: IaaS products provide full infrastructure access, PaaS products mask complexity, and serverless architectures (like AWS Lambda) let developers run code on cloud servers.

reviewQuestions_cap1.questionText: Which of the following best describes scalability?

options.A: The ability of an application to automatically add preconfigured compute resources to meet increasing demand
options.B: The ability of an application to increase or decrease compute resources to match changing demand
options.C: The ability to more densely pack virtualized resources onto a single physical server
options.D: The ability to bill resource usage using a pay-per-user model

reviewQuestions_cap1.answer: The ability of an application to automatically add preconfigured compute resources to meet increasing demand
reviewQuestions_cap1.explanation: Increasing or decreasing compute resources better describes elasticity. Efficient use of virtualized resources and billing models aren’t related directly to scalability.

reviewQuestions_cap1.questionText: Which of the following best describes elasticity?

options.A: The ability to more densely pack virtualized resources onto a single physical server
options.B: The ability to bill resource usage using a pay-per-user model
options.C: The ability of an application to increase or decrease compute resources to match changing demand
options.D: The ability of an application to automatically add preconfigured compute resources to meet increasing demand

reviewQuestions_cap1.answer: The ability of an application to increase or decrease compute resources to match changing demand
reviewQuestions_cap1.explanation: Preconfiguring compute instances before they’re used to scale up an application is an element of scalability rather than elasticity. Efficient use of virtualized resources and billing models aren’t related directly to elasticity.

reviewQuestions_cap1.questionText: Which of the following characteristics most help AWS provide such scalable services? (Choose two.)

options.A: The enormous number of servers it operates
options.B: The value of its capitalized assets
options.C: Its geographic reach
options.D: Its highly automated infrastructure administration systems?

answer: The enormous number of servers it operates
Its highly automated infrastructure administration systems?

reviewQuestions_cap2.questionText: Which of the following EC2 services can be used without charge under the Free Tier?

options.A: Any single EC2 instance type as long as it runs for less than one hour per day
options.B: Any single EC2 instance type as long as it runs for less than 75 hours per month
options.C: A single t2.micro EC2 instance type instance for 750 hours per month
options.D: t2.micro EC2 instance type instances for a total of 750 hours per month

reviewQuestions_cap2.answer: t2.micro EC2 instance type instances for a total of 750 hours per month
reviewQuestions_cap2.explanation: Only the t2.micro instance type is Free Tier–eligible, and any combination of t2.micro instances can be run up to a total of 750 hours per month.

reviewQuestions_cap2.questionText: You want to experiment with deploying a web server on an EC2 instance. Which two of the following resources can you include to make that work while remaining within the Free Tier? (Choose two.)

options.A: A 5 GB bucket on S3
options.B: A t2.micro instance type EC2 instance
options.C: A 30 GB solid-­state Elastic Block Store (EBS) drive
options.D: Two 20 GB solid-­state Elastic Block Store (EBS) drives

answer: A t2.micro instance type EC2 instance
A 30 GB solid-­state Elastic Block Store (EBS) drive
reviewQuestions_cap2.explanation: S3 buckets—while available in such volumes under the Free Tier—are not necessary for an EC2 instance. Since the maximum total EBS space allowed by the Free Tier is 30 GB, two 20 GB would not be covered.

reviewQuestions_cap2.questionText: Which of the following usage will always be cost-­free even after your account’s Free Tier has expired? (Choose two.)

options.A: One million API calls/month on Amazon API Gateway
options.B: 10 GB of data retrievals from Amazon Glacier per month
options.C: 500 MB/month of free storage on the Amazon Elastic Container Registry (ECR)
options.D: 10 custom monitoring metrics and 10 alarms on Amazon CloudWatch

answer: 10 GB of data retrievals from Amazon Glacier per month
10 custom monitoring metrics and 10 alarms on Amazon CloudWatch
reviewQuestions_cap2.explanation: The API calls/month and ECR free storage are available only under the Free Tier.

reviewQuestions_cap2.questionText: Which of the following tools are available to ensure you won’t accidentally run past your Free Tier limit and incur unwanted costs? (Choose two.)

options.A: Automated email alerts when activity approaches the Free Tier limits
options.B: The Top Free Tier Services by Usage section on the Billing & Cost Management Dashboard
options.C: Billing & Cost Management section on the Top Free Tier Services Dashboard
options.D: The Billing Preferences Dashboard

answer: Automated email alerts when activity approaches the Free Tier limits
The Top Free Tier Services by Usage section on the Billing & Cost Management Dashboard
reviewQuestions_cap2.explanation: There is no Top Free Tier Services Dashboard or, for that matter, a Billing Preferences Dashboard.

reviewQuestions_cap2.questionText: Which of the following is likely to be an accurate source of AWS pricing information?

options.A: Wikipedia pages relating to a particular service
options.B: The AWS Command-­Line Interface (AWS CLI)
options.C: AWS online documentation relating to a particular service
options.D: The AWS Pricing Calculator

reviewQuestions_cap2.answer: AWS online documentation relating to a particular service
reviewQuestions_cap2.explanation: Wikipedia pages aren’t updated or detailed enough to be helpful in this respect. The AWS CLI isn’t likely to have much (if any) pricing information. The Pricing Calculator may not contain the absolute latest information about service pricing.

reviewQuestions_cap2.questionText: Which of the following will probably not affect the pricing for an AWS service?

options.A: Requests for raising the available service limit
options.B: AWS region
options.C: The volume of data saved to an S3 bucket
options.D: The volume of data egress from an Amazon S3 Glacier vault

reviewQuestions_cap2.answer: Requests for raising the available service limit
reviewQuestions_cap2.explanation: Pricing will normally change based on the volume of service units you consume and, often, between AWS regions.

reviewQuestions_cap2.questionText: Which of the following AWS documentation URLs points to the page containing an up-­to-­date list of service limits?

options.A: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/general/latest/gr/limits.html
options.B: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/general/latest/gr/aws_service_limits.html
options.C: https://aws.amazon.com/general/latest/gr/aws_service_limits.html
options.D: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/latest/gr/aws_service_limits.html

reviewQuestions_cap2.questionText: Which of the following best describes one possible reason for AWS service limits?

options.A: To prevent individual customers from accidentally launching a crippling level of resource consumption
options.B: To more equally distribute available resources between customers from different regions
options.C: To allow customers to more gradually increase their deployments
options.D: Because there are logical limits to the ability of AWS resources to scale up

reviewQuestions_cap2.answer: To prevent individual customers from accidentally launching a crippling level of resource consumption
reviewQuestions_cap2.explanation: Resource limits exist only within individual regions; the limits in one region don’t impact another. There’s no logistical reason that customers can’t scale up deployments at any rate. There are, in fact, no logical limits to the ability of AWS resources to scale upward.

reviewQuestions_cap2.questionText: Is it always possible to request service limit increases from AWS?

options.A: Yes. All service limits can be increased.
options.B: No. A limit can never be increased.
options.C: Service limits are defaults. They can be increased or decreased on demand.
options.D: No. Some service limits are hard.

reviewQuestions_cap2.answer: No. Some service limits are hard.
reviewQuestions_cap2.explanation: While most service limits are soft and can be raised on request, some service limits exist that are absolute.

reviewQuestions_cap2.questionText: Which is the best place to get a quick summary of this month’s spend for your account?

options.A: Budgets
options.B: Cost Explorer
options.C: Cost and Usage reports
options.D: Billing & Cost Management Dashboard

reviewQuestions_cap2.explanation: The Cost Explorer and Cost and Usage reports provide more in‐depth and/or customized details. Budgets allow you to set alerts based on usage.

reviewQuestions_cap2.questionText: What is the main goal for creating a Usage budget type (in AWS Budgets)?

options.A: To correlate usage per unit cost to understand your account cost efficiency
options.B: To track the status of any active reserved instances on your account
options.C: To track particular categories of resource consumption
options.D: To monitor costs being incurred against your account

reviewQuestions_cap2.answer: To track particular categories of resource consumption
reviewQuestions_cap2.explanation: Reservation budgets track the status of any active reserved instances on your account. Cost budgets monitor costs being incurred against your account. There is no budget type that correlates usage per unit cost to determine your account cost efficiency.

reviewQuestions_cap2.questionText: Which of the following is not a setting you can configure in a Cost budget?

options.A: Period (monthly, quarterly, etc.)
options.B: Instance type
options.C: Start and stop dates
options.D: Owner (username of resource owner)

reviewQuestions_cap2.explanation: You can configure the period, instance type, and start/stop dates for a budget, but you can’t filter by resource owner.

reviewQuestions_cap2.questionText: What is the main difference between the goals of Cost Explorer and of Cost and Usage reports?

options.A: Cost Explorer displays visualizations of high-­level historical and current account costs, whereas Cost and Usage reports generate granular usage reports in CSV format.
options.B: Cost and Usage reports display visualizations of high-­level historical and current account costs, whereas Cost Explorer generates granular usage reports in CSV format.
options.C: Cost Explorer lets you set alerts that are triggered by billing events, whereas Cost and Usage reports help you visualize system events.
options.D: Cost and Usage reports are meant to alert you to malicious intrusions, whereas Cost Explorer displays visualizations of high-­level historical and current account costs.

reviewQuestions_cap2.answer: Cost Explorer displays visualizations of high-­level historical and current account costs, whereas Cost and Usage reports generate granular usage reports in CSV format.
reviewQuestions_cap2.explanation: Billing events aren’t triggers for alerts. Nothing in this chapter discusses intrusion events.

reviewQuestions_cap2.questionText: What is the purpose of cost allocation tags?

options.A: To associate spend limits to automatically trigger resource shutdowns when necessary
options.B: To help you identify the purpose and owner of a particular running resource to better understand and control deployments
options.C: To help you identify resources for the purpose of tracking your account spending
options.D: To visually associate account events with billing periods

reviewQuestions_cap2.answer: To help you identify resources for the purpose of tracking your account spending
reviewQuestions_cap2.explanation: Tags are passive, so they can’t automatically trigger anything. Resource tags—not cost allocation tags—are meant to help you understand and control deployments. Tags aren’t associated with particular billing periods.

reviewQuestions_cap2.questionText: Which of the following scenarios would be a good use case for AWS Organizations? (Choose two.)

options.A: A single company with multiple AWS accounts that wants a single place to administer everything
options.B: An organization that provides AWS access to large teams of its developers and admins
options.C: A company that’s integrated some operations with an upstream vendor
options.D: A company with two distinct operational units, each with its own accounting system and AWS account

answer: A single company with multiple AWS accounts that wants a single place to administer everything
A company that’s integrated some operations with an upstream vendor
reviewQuestions_cap2.explanation: Companies with multiple users of resources in a single AWS account would not benefit from AWS Organizations, nor would a company with completely separated units. The value of AWS Organizations is in integrating the administration of related accounts.

reviewQuestions_cap2.questionText: Which of these tools lets you design graphs within the browser interface to track your account spending?

options.A: Budgets
options.B: Cost Explorer
options.C: Reports
options.D: Consolidating Billing

reviewQuestions_cap2.explanation: Budgets are used to set alerts. Reports provide CSV‐formatted data for offline processing. Consolidated Billing (now migrated to AWS Organizations) is for administering resources across multiple AWS accounts.
